author: Branko
title: Nice build set as well as a decent game.
review:
I was pleasantly surprised when building this set; it makes for a nice display piece and captures the atmosphere of Chima very nicely. It is quite unusual for a Lego game to be nice (for me) as a Lego building set on it own merit which warrants me writing this short review.

Pros

  • The set looks nice when finished, worth displaying next to bigger Chima sets.
  • The build contains nice 'Studs-Not-On-Top' features for Mount Cavora
  • A lot of nice mini-forest details around the base
  • The game is quite decent to play and can easily be modified to be more strategic (less random) or even more random if you so choose.
  • The micro Chima characters are cute
  • My 8-year old kids enjoy playing the game.
  • Only source of Chima micro-figures (12 of them!)

Cons

  • Mount Cavora is not mounted very sturdily so it falls over quite easily.
  • The game is more strategic when not using the die, although younger kids probably like the random nature of the special tiles on the die.
  • The game is very quick. Sometimes it feels nice to be able to drag it out a bit more.
  • The game had the potential of being more strategic such as the game Carcasonne but fall short due to the compulsory inclusion of the die.

If you like the Chima range, like I do, I would say this set is a must have, since it captures the essence and atmosphere of the theme so nicely. The reason I only give it a 4/5 rating though is because the whole set is very small scale and there are nicer builds and  mini-figures to be had at this price range. This is one of the nicer Lego Games that I've laid my hands on, and I do have quite an extensive collection.
